channel.title: Machine Learning on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.description: Recent content in Machine Learning on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.copyright: Text and figures licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 by Yanir Seroussi, except where noted otherwise

item.title: AI/ML lifecycle models versus real-world mess
item.description: The real world of AI/ML doesn’t fit into a neat diagram, so I created another diagram and a maturity heatmap to model the mess.

item.title: Is your tech stack ready for data-intensive applications?
item.description: Questions to assess the quality of tech stacks and lifecycles, with a focus on artificial intelligence, machine learning, and analytics.

item.title: Dealing with endless data changes
item.description: Quotes from Demetrios Brinkmann on the relationship between MLOps and DevOps, with MLOps allowing for managing changes that come from data.

item.title: Assessing a startup's data-to-AI health
item.description: Reviewing the areas that should be assessed to determine a startup’s opportunities and challenges on the data/AI/ML front.

item.title: AI does not obviate the need for testing and observability
item.description: It’s easy to prototype with AI, but production-grade AI apps require even more thorough testing and observability than traditional software.

item.title: Artificial intelligence, automation, and the art of counting fish
item.description: Discussing the use of AI to automate underwater marine surveys as an example of the uneven distribution of technological advancement.

item.title: Questions to consider when using AI for PDF data extraction
item.description: Discussing considerations that arise when attempting to automate the extraction of structured data from PDFs and similar documents.

item.title: Two types of startup data problems
item.description: Classifying startups as ML-centric or non-ML is a helpful exercise to uncover the data challenges they’re likely to face.

item.title: Avoiding AI complexity: First, write no code
item.description: Two stories of getting AI functionality to production, which demonstrate the risks inherent in custom development versus starting with a no-code approach.

item.title: Transfer learning applies to energy market bidding
item.description: An interesting approach to bidding of energy storage assets, showing that training on New York data is transferable to Queensland.

item.title: Supporting volunteer monitoring of marine biodiversity with modern web and data tools
item.description: Summarising the work Uri Seroussi and I did to improve Reef Life Survey’s Reef Species of the World app.

item.title: Google's Rules of Machine Learning still apply in the age of large language models
item.description: Despite the excitement around large language models, building with machine learning remains an engineering problem with established best practices.

item.title: ChatGPT is transformative AI
item.description: My perspective after a week of using ChatGPT: This is a step change in finding distilled information, and it’s only the beginning.

item.title: Causal Machine Learning is off to a good start, despite some issues
item.description: Reviewing the first three chapters of the book Causal Machine Learning by Robert Osazuwa Ness.

item.title: Building useful machine learning tools keeps getting easier: A fish ID case study
item.description: Lessons learned building a fish ID web app with fast.ai and Streamlit, in an attempt to reduce my fear of missing out on the latest deep learning developments.

item.title: Use your human brain to avoid artificial intelligence disasters
item.description: Overview of a talk I gave at a deep learning course, focusing on AI ethics as the need for humans to think on the context and consequences of applying AI.

item.title: My work with Automattic
item.description: Back-dated meta-post that gathers my posts on Automattic blogs into a summary of the work I’ve done with the company.

item.title: Defining data science in 2018
item.description: Updating my definition of data science to match changes in the field. It is now broader than before, but its ultimate goal is still to support decisions.

item.title: Why you should stop worrying about deep learning and deepen your understanding of causality instead
item.description: Causality is often overlooked but is of much higher relevance to most data scientists than deep learning.

item.title: Miscommunicating science: Simplistic models, nutritionism, and the art of storytelling
item.description: Nutritionism is a special case of misinterpretation and miscommunication of scientific results – something many data scientists encounter in their work.

item.title: The wonderful world of recommender systems
item.description: Giving an overview of the field and common paradigms, and debunking five common myths about recommender systems.

item.title: Learning about deep learning through album cover classification
item.description: Progress on my album cover classification project, highlighting lessons that would be useful to others who are getting started with deep learning.

item.title: Hopping on the deep learning bandwagon
item.description: To become proficient at solving data science problems, you need to get your hands dirty. Here, I used album cover classification to learn about deep learning.

item.title: First steps in data science: author-aware sentiment analysis
item.description: I became a data scientist by doing a PhD, but the same steps can be followed without a formal education program.

item.title: My PhD work
item.description: An overview of my PhD in data science / artificial intelligence. Thesis title: Text Mining and Rating Prediction with Topical User Models.

item.title: Learning to rank for personalised search (Yandex Search Personalisation – Kaggle Competition Summary – Part 2)
item.description: My team’s solution to the Yandex Search Personalisation competition (finished 9th out of 194 teams).

item.title: Is thinking like a search engine possible? (Yandex search personalisation – Kaggle competition summary – part 1)
item.description: Insights on search personalisation and SEO from participating in a Kaggle competition (finished 9th out of 194 teams).

item.title: Stochastic Gradient Boosting: Choosing the Best Number of Iterations
item.description: Exploring an approach to choosing the optimal number of iterations in stochastic gradient boosting, following a bug I found in scikit-learn.
